captions.text: (TL;DR Music)

(A TUBA GOES: DA DA DA DA DA DA DA 
 DA, DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA)

(TUBA, SYNTH GO: DA DA DA DA DA DA DA 
 DA, DA DA DA DA DA DA DA DA)
[M] Angelicad7 from Chicago, USA asks,

[S] "Is there a Korean product that you can't live without and 
 thought to yourself, why haven't they introduced this back home?"
[S] Yes, Angelicad7, yes there are. [M] Yes, there is.
(Disagreeing over whether to use 'is' or 'are' for proper English)

[M] Yes there are lots of them. [S] Ares, 
 lots of them. (Incorrect to say ares)
[M] Underline g for grammar. Shouldn't be 'is' it should be 'are'.
Simon, gosh. (With attitude)
[S] I said 'are', you said 'is'. [M] Pfft~ Prove it.
No instant replay, Noooooooooooooo.
[M] Now, since we've been living in Korea for around four years,

we don't know if these products have already come to North America, 
 or maybe they are already in other parts of the world.
So, if they do already exist there, and we sound really stupid...
[S] My bad. [M] Sorry guys. [S] Sorry.
[M] And if you already have them, lucky duckies.
That's right I said it. Lucky duckies. [S] Lucky duckies?
[S] Are we talking like senior citizens all of a sudden?

[Martina's deep low voice] Back in my day, I used to 
 use the computer that boot up on a modem.

[S] So, the first thing that pops into 
 mind automatically is table bells. (Twinkling sound)

[M] I can't believe you said that; that 
 was mine. I was gonna say it.
[S] It's ours, we both feel the same way about it.
[M] Really? Because the table bell is my most favoritest thing ever in Korea.
[S] Underline g for grammar.
[M] What? It's a word. Favoritest. (No, no it's not Martina.)

So, when you go to a Korean restaurant, they have 
 a kind of  box on the table.

It doesn't look like a bell, not like a 
 bing. (the sound) It's like a box.

And you push it, and it will ring a 
 bell to the back of the restaurant.
Some will show your table number and some are just a sound.
The waitress will come over and, you know, take your order,
refill your water, and do whatever they have to do.
Otherwise, they completely leave you alone. Isn't that awesome?
[S] Why don't they have this is North America?

Like, I don't want my waiter or waitress coming every five 
 minutes and ask me if I need more coffee.

[M] Excuse me, did you need a refill 
 for your soda? [S] No, I don't.
[M] How's your meal right now? [S] I'm doing alright.
[S] And... [M] Did you want to order from the dessert specials today?
[S] I'm good, thanks. [M] We have apple crumble and milkshake. [S] Hey,
you know what? In Korea, they don't work for tips.
[M] So, we think that's the real big difference. Because there is no tipping,

there's no need for you to flutter up to someone's table, 
 like a hummingbird on super sugar, ask too many questions.
Beeeeiiinnng, Beeeeiiiiinnnnng. (Sounds of birds chirping)
[S] You know what, you're cut off from the coffee, missy.

Next thing I want to talk about is my 
 bank card. Yes I know that sounds lame,
but you don't understand how awesome this bank card is.

I can use a bank card, of course, for buying 
 stuff at the restaurants, buying groceries, or going shopping.
But, it does a lot more than that as well.

If I want to get on the subway, 
 I swipe my band card. That's it.

I don't have to like run it through anything. I just hover 
 it above, it will automatically beep through, and charge my account
to get on the subway. It's the same thing if I'm in a taxi.

I don't have to swipe it in the taxi. I 
 just wave my card over the little card wave-o-meter,
[M] Abracadabra. [S] whatever you call it. It winds up automatically going through.

And, what's super awesome about it is that everytime I buy 
 something with my card, my phone gets a text message
telling me exactly where it was bought and how much I paid for it.

[M] So, if Simon loses the card somewhere, you might be like, 
 oh god, people are going to spend taxi money and stuff.

But, you get a message right away on his phone being like, dude 
 is using your card, then Simon can call and cancel right away.
[S] The NFC payments they have here, brilliant system.
[M] The next thing on our list is something you might have seen before
when we did the tour of our officetel.
It's our keypad door lock, and it's so friggin future.

There's two different options for these. Instead of using like a key to 
 get in the house, you can have a little magnetic stick.

It just looks like a stick with a magnet, and you push it up 
 against this little, blue button, and it goes like bwee dee dee.
That's it, it's open.
And the second option is actually a 'no metallic little lock thingy',
but it's just a little keypad with a secret code.
[S] Who needs keys? Our keys are like from the 700's,
like these are so old. We should be living in the future.
Last time we visited Canada, like.... [S] Oh my godddd.

[M] I mean, we're in our late twenties, and we got locked 
 out of my parents' house like I was a teenager.
We had no cellphone because we were just visiting,
and we had no keys. So, we're sitting on the porch like...
[S] like barbarians, okay?

[M] I was like, should I break in the windows 
 or are the cops going to be called?
Because there's a suspicious blonde girl with pink hair.

[S] And the last thing, is our newest toy 
 on the list. This is an EGG.
Essentially what this thing is, it's a 4G hotspot.
It essentially takes all the signals of the Koreas.

(Yes, Simon and Martina are having trouble with words 
 today, making it hard to subtitle them.)
(Martina laughs) And, it makes a 4G wifi hotspot.
So I can connect my laptop to it, my iPad, my iPhone.
I think you can connect up to about five different devices to this.
[M] We can connect our friends, and we can get signals anywhere we want.
facetiming with my parents in Canada. It's so cool.

So, we will be on the bus, going 
 in between cities and I'll be like,
They're like, where are you? I'm like, I'm crossing over the Bridger in Seoul.
The Bridger is a bridge and a river connected together.
It's a Bridger.

[S] Thanks. [M] oh. [S] And, this thing only 
 costs about an extra ten bucks a month.
[S] I think North America is starting to get something like this,

but I think it might cost a lot more, 
 and it's not as awesome as this.
Because this is ten bucks a month.
[M] Yeah. Plus, 4G. Are we the fastest internet in the world now?
Or second fastest? [S] No, we are the fastest internet in the world.
[M] Korea: forget about the hanbok and the kimchi.
Come for the fastest internet in the world.
[S] So, that's it for this TL;DR.
If there is a question you want us to answer for next TL;DR,
leave your question on the Goggle moderator page.
Or, check out the questions already asked,
and you can vote them up or you can vote them down.
[S] And, don't forget to subscribe for more TL:DR's.
[M] Thanks for such a fun and really uplifting question.
[S] Yes. [M] I gonna drink more coffee. Beeeeee.

(Gong) Thanks for watching this TL;DR of EYK.
(Sexy Intoxication music)

title: TL;DR - Korean Products We Can't Live Without
